objtitle.title: *King Sebert, from the Wall-Painting in the Sedilia above His Monument*

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe work is numbered "II." in pencil top right.

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society shortly after its engraving for Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, first published by the Society of Antiquaries in 1780.

desc.objtitle:
King Sebert, from the Wall-Painting in the Sedilia above His Monument,
Object 1 (BUT8.1)

objnote.p: The collection stamp of the Society of Antiquaries appears bottom center left below the design. A larger, circular collection stamp of the Society appears lower right. A water color replica (Butlin 16) of this water color is in the Bodleian Library, Oxford. An engraving of this design was published in Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, Plate 5 (1780), and in *Vetusta Monumenta*, volume 2 of c. 1789, Plate 33.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design, part of the wall painting in the sedilia above King Sebert's monument at Westminster Abbey, is a panel with a solid background (perhaps of stone?) and a narrow border, which contains beveling, two columns, and a plain arch. Inside the arch are four points of a decorative tracery, each containing a gilded trefoil design and terminating in a leaf. The two points nearest the arch's top are smaller and more compressed. In the center of the arching panel is a crowned man who represents King Sebert. The king wears a long-sleeved gown, a long robe, gloves, and a crown. His hair and beard are curly. The king faces forward and to the right, bending with his upper body toward the pillar at his right. His left arm is bent upward, and he points upward with his index finger. His right arm is bent with his forearm raised horizontally, and he holds a decorative scepter that extends from his waist over his right shoulder.

component.illusobjdesc: The design represents the wall-painting of King Sebert in the sedilia above his monument in Westminster Abbey. It contains a tall, narrow, painted panel with a solid background (perhaps of stone?) and surrounded by a narrow border. The horizontal lower border suggests a beveled design.

The design represents the wall-painting of King Sebert in the sedilia above his monument in Westminster Abbey. Forming the vertical portions of this border are the inside halves of two columns or pillars; the left column appears to be segmented, and the right bears a cross-hatching pattern. The arching upper portions of this border are plain, but inside the arch are four points of a decorative tracery, each containing a gilded trefoil design and terminating in a leaf. The two points nearest the arch's top are smaller and more compressed.
Each of the four points of the decorative tracery near the top of the design appears to end in a decorative leaf.

In the center of the arching panel is painted a crowned man who represents King Sebert. The king wears a long-sleeved gown with a decorated collar. The gown extends to the floor and is partially covered by a long, flowing robe with a bordered, curling hem. He wears gloves on both hands. His hair and beard are curly, and a crown decorated with four (visible) leaves sits atop his head. The king faces forward and to the right, bending with his upper body toward the right. His head bends right and downward, but his eyes are raised. His left arm is bent upward, and he points upward with his index finger. The other fingers of his left hand are curled into a loose fist. His right arm is bent with his forearm raised horizontally, and he holds in his extended fingers a decorative scepter that extends from his waist over his right shoulder, where it may rest.
King Sebert holds a scepter in his right hand. The upper end of the scepter is decorated with a gold design that resembles a Gothic structure.

phystext.p: II.This pencil inscription was probably not written by Blake.

foot IThis inscription and line 3, both in pen and ink, record the height of the design. They are written vertically along the right side of the design. These inscription were probably not written by Blake.
Basire. del.This pen and ink inscription, a reference to or signature of Blake's engraving master James Basire, was probably not written by Blake.
foot IThis inscription and line 6, both in pen and ink, record the width of the design. These inscriptions were probably not written by Blake.

Figure supposed to be that of King Sebert on the North front of his Tomb. Westmr. Abbey vide Vetutst. Mon. Vol. II. pl. 33.This pen and ink inscription is probably not by Blake. "Vetutst. Mon. Vol. II. pl. 33" is a reference to volume 2 of *Vetusta Monumenta*, published by the Society of Antiquaries c. 1789. An engraving of this design, signed by Blake's engraving master James Basire, was published as plate 33 in that volume.
